section_1_sacred_text.original_script: καὶ νῦν πέμψον ⸂ἄνδρας εἰς Ἰόππην⸃ καὶ μετάπεμψαι Σίμωνά ⸂τινα ὃς ἐπικαλεῖται Πέτρος⸃·
section_1_sacred_text.faithful_direct_translation: And now, send men to Joppa and summon a certain Simon who is also called Peter.
section_1_sacred_text.standalone_english_translation: Now send men to Joppa and call for Simon, whose surname is Peter.
section_1_sacred_text.amplified_narrative_translation: Therefore, at this very moment, you are to dispatch men immediately to the port city of Joppa, and you are to specifically summon to your presence a man named Simon, the one who is also known by the surname Peter.

section_2_exegetical_synthesis: This verse is a direct, unambiguous command from an angelic messenger to a Roman centurion named Cornelius, delivered within a vision.
The text is historical narrative (Sensus Literalis), recording a pivotal, literal event, not an allegory or parable.
The action commanded—sending for Peter—serves as the catalyst for the formal, apostolic opening of the gospel to the Gentile world.
This moment is the historical antitype, or fulfillment, of God's foundational promise to Abraham that 'in you all the families of the earth shall be blessed' (Genesis 12:3).
It is the apostolic realization of the prophetic theme that Israel's Messiah would be a 'light for the nations' (Isaiah 42:6, 49:6), bringing God's salvation to the ends of the earth.
The command to Cornelius actualizes the Great Commission of Jesus to 'make disciples of all nations' (Matthew 28:19), moving the early church past its initial Judeo-centric focus.
The narrative stands as a stark reversal of the story of the prophet Jonah, who fled from God's command to preach to Gentiles by boarding a ship at the very same port, Joppa (Jonah 1:3).
Peter, in Joppa, is being summoned to embrace the Gentiles, correcting Jonah's rebellious flight and fulfilling Israel's true calling.
The angel issues two urgent commands: `πέμψον` (pempson, 'send') and `μετάπεμψαι` (metapempsai, 'send for'/'summon').
Both are aorist active imperatives, grammatical forms indicating decisive, specific actions to be carried out without delay.
The command is given to Cornelius, a centurion of the 'Italian Cohort,' a unit likely composed of Roman citizens from Italy, marking him as an unambiguous, high-status Gentile.
His description as one who 'feared God' (Acts 10:2) identifies him as a Gentile worshipper of Yahweh, sympathetic to Judaism but not a full proselyte.
The destination is `Ἰόππην` (Ioppēn), the port city of Joppa, from the Hebrew `יָפוֹ` (Yāfō, 'beautiful').
The man to be summoned is `Σίμωνά` (Simōna), from the Hebrew `שִׁמְעוֹן` (Šimʿôn, 'he has heard').
The theological significance is that God has 'heard' the prayers of the Gentile Cornelius (Acts 10:4, 31) and is now sending the apostle named 'Hearing' to deliver His message.
He is further identified as the one `ὃς ἐπικαλεῖται Πέτρος` (hos epikaleitai Petros, 'who is surnamed Peter').
`Πέτρος` (Petros) means 'a rock' or 'stone,' the apostolic name given to him by Jesus (John 1:42).
The apostle who was called the 'Rock' (Matthew 16:18) is now being used to lay the foundational stone of the Gentile mission, expanding the church beyond its Jewish origins.
The use of both names, Simon Peter, often signifies the intersection of the man's natural identity and his divine, apostolic calling.
The historical setting is approximately A.D. 40-41, during the reign of Roman Emperor Caligula or shortly after Claudius ascended.
The socio-political context is one of extreme tension and separation between Jews and Gentiles.

Pious Jews would not enter a Gentile home or eat with them, viewing them as ritually unclean (Acts 10:28), a barrier rooted in interpretations of the Mosaic Law designed to prevent pagan syncretism (Deuteronomy 7:3-4).
Peter's subsequent journey into the home of a Roman centurion would be a radical, taboo-shattering act, requiring a direct vision from God to authorize (Acts 10:9-16).
Cornelius was stationed in Caesarea Maritima (Lat/Long: 32.50° N, 34.90° E; Altitude: Sea level), the Roman administrative capital of Judea.
Peter was staying in Joppa, modern Jaffa (Lat/Long: 32.05° N, 34.75° E; Altitude: Sea level to 40m), a major port city.
The distance between Caesarea and Joppa is approximately 32 miles (51 km) along the Via Maris, a journey of over one full day for Cornelius's men (Acts 10:7-9, 23-24).
The terrain is the flat, easily-traversable coastal plain of Sharon.

Archaeological excavations at Caesarea have confirmed its status as the Roman capital, unearthing the theater, harbor, aqueduct, and an inscription mentioning Pontius Pilate, who preceded the governor of this period.

The traditional site of the 'House of Simon the Tanner' in Jaffa is located by the sea, consistent with the logistical needs of tanning, a trade considered 'unclean' by many Jews which required access to water.

This divinely-orchestrated event breaks down the 'dividing wall of hostility' (Ephesians 2:14), demonstrating that God shows no partiality (Acts 10:34) and that salvation is available to all who believe, Jew and Gentile alike (Romans 1:16).
It is the historic moment that unlocks the 'mystery' of the Gospel: that the Gentiles are fellow heirs and members of the same body through Christ (Ephesians 3:6).
Peter himself later cites this event as the definitive proof that God had chosen him to open the door of faith to the Gentiles (Acts 15:7).
section_3_life_application: Recognize that God's specific instructions often require us to step beyond our personal comfort zones and cross social, cultural, or racial barriers we have erected.
Respond to God's leading with immediate obedience, just as Cornelius did, even when you don't yet understand the full purpose or outcome.
Actively look for the 'divine appointments' God is orchestrating, where He brings you into contact with people from different backgrounds for the sake of the Gospel.
Confront and dismantle any personal prejudice or bias, asking God to give you His heart for all people, seeing them not by their external status but as individuals for whom Christ died.
Understand that your personal obedience to a specific, seemingly small command from God can be a critical link in the chain of His grand, redemptive plan for others.
Be a 'Peter' whom God can send, and be a 'Cornelius' who is willing to listen and seek—be prepared to both carry the message and to receive it in unexpected ways from unexpected people.
